leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.18] r 6.18 Joinder of causes of action (cf SCR Part 8, rule 1; DCR Part 7, rule 1; LCR Part 6, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Joinder of causes of action (cf SCR Part 8, rule 1; DCR Part 7, rule 1; LCR Part 6, rule 1)

p.text: In any originating process, the plaintiff may claim relief against the defendant in respect of more than one cause of action in the any of following circumstances:
if the plaintiff sues in the same capacity, and claims the defendant to be liable in the same capacity, in respect of each cause of action,
if the plaintiff sues:
in his or her capacity as executor of the will of a deceased person, or administrator of the estate of a deceased person, in respect of one or more of the causes of action, and
in his or her personal capacity, but with reference to the estate of the same deceased person, in respect of the remaining causes of action,
if the plaintiff claims the defendant to be liable:
in his or her capacity as executor of the will of a deceased person, or administrator of the estate of a deceased person, in respect of one or more of the causes of action, and
in his or her personal capacity, and in relation to the estate of the same deceased person, in respect of the remaining causes of action,
if the court grants leave for all of the causes of action to be dealt with in the same proceedings.
Leave under subrule (1) may be granted before or after the originating process is filed.

The expression “cause of action” has, depending on its context, a certain degree of imprecision. Sometimes it is used to mean the facts that support a right to judgment: Williams v Milotin (1957) 97 CLR 465 at 474 (“the essential ingredients to the right which it is proposed to enforce”). Read v Brown (1888) 22 QBD 128 at 131 (“every fact which is necessary to be proved”); Letang v Cooper [1965] 1 QB 232 at 242 ; Bennett v White [1910] 2 KB 643 . Sometimes it is used to mean the substance of the right that has been infringed as distinct from its form: Jackson v Spittall (1870) LR 5 CP 542 at 552; Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (1981) 147 CLR 589 at 610; 36 ALR 3; BC8100097 per Brennan J. Given the permissive language of the present rule the choice between these various meanings is not critical. However the basic purpose of the rule is probably most consistent with regarding “cause of action” as referring to the second of the possible meanings referred to by Brennan J — namely the “right that has been infringed”.

(NSW) Compensation to Relatives Act 1897.

Subrule (1)(b) of the present rule is directed to the situation where an executor or administrator has been dealing with the estate in the due course of administration and where questions may arise as to whether there is a personal, as distinct from a merely representative, liability: Padwick v Scott (1876) 2 Ch D 736 at 743 . The rule permits joinder of causes of action where the claim based upon the executor’s alleged personal liability is related to the estate. If the claims are not related in this way then leave is required: Whitworth v Darbishire (1893) 41 WR 317; Re Richardson [1933] WN (Eng) 90; [1933] 175 LT Jo 269. For example, leave is required to join a personal claim for damages against the executor with a claim under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1897 .

level.toc-caption: [6.18.15] Leave to join causes of action

heading.title: Leave to join causes of action

p.text: Leave may be granted before or after the originating process is filed. The right to seek leave extends to any case in which a combination of claims is desired and where for any reason, including the fact that the proceedings have already been initiated, it is appropriate for the different claims to be dealt with together.
Legislation cited in [6.18.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 6.22, 6.32.

Misjoinder of causes of action will be treated as a mere irregularity. Although it has been held that a defendant who takes any step in the action other than entering an appearance may waive right to object: Hunt v Worsfold [1896] 2 Ch 224 ; Lloyd v Great Western Dairies [1907] 2 KB 727 ; Beugelaar v Springdale County Council [1969] VR 1; any such waiver could not preclude appropriate exercise of the court’s power to give appropriate directions. The directions the court can give include an order striking out part of the claim: Whitworth v Darbishire (1893) 41 WR 317; or an order for separate trials: see rr 6.22 and 6.32 .
Legislation cited in [6.18.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.18(1)(d).
(NSW) Conveyancing Act 1919 s 72.

Although there is nothing in the rules to require that a party indicate that they sue, or are sued, in a representative capacity, that fact should appear in the initiating process. Any judgment should also indicate the capacity of the defendant. The purpose of this is to clarify whether the judgment may be enforced personally against the defendant or only to the extent of the representative capacity: Levy v Kum Chah (1936) 56 CLR 159 at 168; [1937] ALR 10; BC3700072 ; Government Insurance Offıce (NSW) v Johnson [1981] 2 NSWLR 617 at 622 (capacity of a representative to bind a deceased defendant’s estate); Lahoud v Lahoud [2009] NSWSC 623; BC200905736 at [302] (defendant entered into terms of settlement in personal capacity as well as representative capacity). The same party cannot be both plaintiff and defendant, even though different interests are involved: Re Bubnich; Marian v Bubnich [1965] WAR 138 . Where this might occur, a manager of a company or a beneficiary in an estate may be appointed a representative party: Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v A-G (1937) 54 WN (NSW) 95 . The principle in Whitworth v Darbishire (1893) 41 WR 317 extends beyond claims against executors in their capacity as such and in their personal capacities. Thus, unless leave is obtained under r 6.18(1)(d) a party cannot be sued twice in the one action, once in his or her personal capacity and again in a representative capacity: Hardie and Lane Ltd v Chiltern [1928] 1 KB 663 . There, the plaintiffs who were members of an association sued three other members of the association who were named twice in the initiating process, being sued “on their own behalf and on behalf of all other members of the association”. The joinder was held to be irregular. For a case where a person is suing himself on a covenant made pursuant to Conveyancing Act 1919 s 72 , see Stewart v Hawkins (1956) 73 WN (NSW) 527 , further proceedings (1960) SR (NSW) 104; 76 WN (NSW) 144.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.19] r 6.19 Proceedings involving common questions of law or fact (cf SCR Part 8, rule 2; DCR Part 7, rule 2; LCR Part 6, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings involving common questions of law or fact (cf SCR Part 8, rule 2; DCR Part 7, rule 2; LCR Part 6, rule 2)

p.text: Two or more persons may be joined as plaintiffs or defendants in any originating process if:
separate proceedings by or against each of them would give rise to a common question of law or fact, and
all rights of relief claimed in the originating process are in respect of, or arise out of, the same transaction or series of transactions,
or if the court gives leave for them to be joined.
Leave under subrule (1) may be granted before or after the originating process is filed.

level.toc-caption: [6.19.5] Joinder permissible in originating process — general considerations

heading.title: Joinder permissible in originating process — general considerations

p.text: The origin and scope of the rule was discussed by the High Court in Payne v Young (1980) 145 CLR 609 at 618; 30 ALR 577 at 582; 54 ALJR 448; BC8000090 (below), and by Mahoney JA in Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Little Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 at 45–53 , noted at [6.18.5] .
The joinder permission granted by the rule has four important features. They are that the rule:

applies to joinder by the moving parties in the proceedings: Walker v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia (1985) 3 NSWLR 496 at 503 ; Payne v Young (1980) 145 CLR 609 at 618; 30 ALR 577; 54 ALJR 448; BC8000090 ;
cumulatively requires “common” questions and “sameness” of transactions;
requires all relief rights to arise out of those transactions: Walker v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, above;
rule contains a general discretion to permit joinder in other cases.

These features of the rule, and specifically its reference to “same” transactions, developed to overcome the practical inconvenience of early decisions restricting the joinder of parties to proceedings involving essentially the same cause of action: Smurthwaite v Hannay [1894] AC 494; (1894) 71 LT 157 (multiple claimants to cargo consisting of unlabelled cotton bales). They clearly establish that joinder under the present rule is not confined to the mere addition of parties: Australian Coastal Shipping Commission v Curtis Cruising Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 734 at 738 per Mahoney JA. It permits different plaintiffs to join several causes of action against the same, or different, defendants: Universities of Oxford & Cambridge v Gill [1899] 1 Ch 55 at 59; (1898) 68 LJ Ch 34; 79 LT 338; 15 TLR 21 . As long as the joinder reflects a sufficient commonality of law, fact or transaction, it is permissible even if a particular defendant is not affected by the whole of the relief sought: Webster v Shaw (1904) 29 VLR 987 , so long as some relief is sought by the plaintiff against that defendant: Walker v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia (1985) 3 NSWLR 496 at 503 .

level.toc-caption: [6.19.10] Same transactions or series of transactions — common questions of law or fact — entitlement to join interested parties

heading.title: Same transactions or series of transactions — common questions of law or fact — entitlement to join interested parties

p.text: Joinder is a matter of right if there is some common question of law or fact, and the various causes of action arise out of the “same transaction or series of transactions.” That expression was originally suggested by Lord Esher MR to resolve the practical difficulties presented in Hannay v Smurthwaite [1893] 2 QB 412 at 420 ; while at the same time providing a proper limit to the scope of the joinder discretion. Plainly the expression is intended to permit some liberality of interpretation and should be so construed: Payne v British Time Recorder Co Ltd [1921] 2 KB 1 at 16 . The concept of a “transaction” is not confined to contractual dealings: Bendir v Anson [1936] 3 All ER 326 at 330 ; Green v Berliner [1936] 2 KB 477 at 484 ; Miliss Pty Ltd v Kerin (Fed C of A, Morling J, 22 June 1988, unreported). It extends, for example, to defamation claims where it indicates the “same publication or series of publications”: Smith v Foley [1912] VLR 314 . It is not necessary that each proposed party is involved in all of the transactions: Stroud v Lawson [1898] 2 QB 44 at 54–5 . Nor is it necessary that each cause of action involve all of the transactions: Markt & Co Ltd v Knight Steamship Co Ltd [1910] 2 KB 1021 .

On the other hand, the “same transaction” criterion was also intended to indicate the limits of the joinder permission. Although the expression only ambiguously expressed the intended limit, the rule does not permit joinder (without leave) where there are merely similar transactions: Payne v Young (1980) 145 CLR 609 at 618; 30 ALR 577 at 582; BC8000090 (claims by seven abattoir owners for the recovery of inspection fees paid under protest to eight separate defendants could not be joined in the one proceeding); Trade Practices Commission v Queensland Aggregates Pty Ltd (1981) 51 FLR 356 . Thus where multiple plaintiffs each enter separate transactions with defendants as a result of separate, though similar, misrepresentations, there is no “series of transactions”: Bishop v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1990) 25 FCR 311 . And where the causes of action are really distinct they cannot be joined without leave: Marino v Esanda Ltd [1986] VR 735 at 740 ; Dean-Willcocks v Cmr of Taxation (2003) 45 ACSR 298; [2003] NSWSC 355; BC200302121 (common factual issue concerning solvency of related companies); Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1991) ATPR ¶41-078; BC9001594.

The rule does not require different plaintiffs to join in the same proceedings: English v Bloom [1936] 2 KB 550 . And consideration should be given to the question whether it is really either practical or desirable to make the joinder. As opposed to the saving of costs potentially involved in having only one set of proceedings, the following factors ought to be considered:
all plaintiffs must ordinarily act by the same solicitor and counsel: Lewis v Daily Telegraph Ltd (No 2) [1964] 2 QB 601; [1964] 1 All ER 705 ;
accordingly there is no room for dissension or conflict of interests between plaintiffs;
co-plaintiffs may be liable for the increased costs occasioned by adding an unsuccessful plaintiff;
a solvent plaintiff is at risk if he or she joins with an insolvent plaintiff in speculative proceedings;
cross-claims may be brought against individual co-plaintiffs;
a co-plaintiff may be interrogated or have to give discovery;
a co-plaintiff may cause embarrassment through non-compliance with directions of the court;
costs will usually be increased if the proceedings become more complicated by the joinder.

level.toc-caption: [6.19.25] Joinder of defendants — examples of joinder

heading.title: Joinder of defendants — examples of joinder

p.text: The rule authorises joinder in a range of different situations. Joinder is not confined to cases where there are alternative claims. Nor do the claims have to be consistent: Child v Stenning (1877) 5 Ch D 695 ; Chadwick v Bridge (1951) 83 CLR 314 ; Sharp v McGivney [1951] VLR 143 . A simple instance of permissible joinder occurs where it is necessary to bind everyone whose interests are capable of being affected by the proceedings. Thus, joinder is permissible where the defendants are both interested in the same property: Stein v Blake [1996] AC 243 at 259 (partial assignment). It is also permissible, in proceedings to enforce an equitable interest, to join the owner of the legal interest: Chapman v Luminis Pty Ltd (1998) 86 FCR 513; BC9804496 (assignment allegedly ineffective at law); McIntyre v Gye (1994) 51 FCR 472 at 480; BC9406001 (equitable assignment of legal right of action). Another common instance of joinder occurs where different causes of action are brought either against the same defendant or against multiple, and alternative, defendants: Bullock v London General Omnibus Co [1907] 1 KB 264 at 271 (alternative defendants with causes of action in contract and tort). For example, passengers injured in the same motor vehicle accident may sue both drivers in the same proceedings. Similarly, principal and agent may be sued in the alternative: Honduras Railway v Lefevre (1877) 2 Ex D 301 at 305; Bennetts v McIlwraith [1896] 2 QB 464 ; Sanderson v Blyth Theatre Co [1903] 2 KB 533 . See also Payne v British Time Recorder Co Ltd [1921] 2 KB 1 ; Petersen v Moloney (1951) 84 CLR 91 . And where loss is alleged to have arisen from an occurrence or transaction which was the subject of professional advice, alternative claims are commonly brought against the other party and against the professional adviser: Birtles v Commonwealth [1960] VR 247 (joinder of alternative claim against a tortfeasor and solicitor where tortfeasor’s defence raised the solicitor’s failure to give statutory notice of a claim).

(NSW) Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 6(4).

Some statutory provisions require a cause of action to be brought against a tortfeasor’s insurer: see for example, Motor Vehicles (Third Party Insurance) Act 1942 s 14 . Other provisions permit proceedings to be taken against a tortfeasor’s insurer: Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 6(4) . Aside from proceedings authorised by such legislative provisions, proper joinder of an insurer presupposes there is some issue between the insurer and the insured in relation to the proceedings: Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Price Waterhouse (1996) 68 SASR 19 at 35; 189 LSJS 364; BC9606539 ; “McCarthy, Third party access to insurance policies and joinder of insurers”, (1999) 11 Ins LJ 46. Consequently, the mere fact that an insurer has assumed the control of the insured’s defence of the litigation does not justify joining the insurer as a party: CE Heath Casualty & General Insurance Ltd v Pyramid Building Society [1997] 2 VR 256; BC9605121 . Even where there was a justiciable issue between insured and insurer, there was some historical reluctance (which must be taken to have declined with the limited use of civil juries in New South Wales — see s 85 of the Supreme Court Act 1970) to permit an insurer to be joined as a third party in proceedings involving a jury trial: Carpenter v Ebblewhite [1939] 1 KB 347 — distinguished in Harman v Crilly [1943] 1 KB 168 (non-jury trial); Gibson v Parkes District Hospital (1991) 26 NSWLR 9 at 14 . The more contemporary position is illustrated by JN Taylor Holdings Ltd (in liq) v Bond (1993) 59 SASR 432; BC9304569 where a plaintiff was permitted to join an insurer as a defendant in order to bind the insurer on the determination of facts which were relevant both to the plaintiff's claim against the principal defendant and to that defendant's entitlement to indemnity from the insurer. Nevertheless, the liability of the insured (to the plaintiff) and the liability of the insurer (to the insured) will commonly involve substantially different issues and where that is the case, it may be both possible and desirable to determine the insurer's liability as a separate matter (either before or after) the hearing of the insured's liability to the plaintiff: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Yuill (NSWSC, Young J, No 1907/94, 6 August 1997, unreported, BC9704052) at p 12; Lissenden v Yorkville Nominees Pty Ltd (in liq) [1984] 3 NSWLR 138 ; Marr Contracting Pty Ltd v FAI Insurances Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers J, No 28015/97, 8 December 1987, unreported, BC8700879); contra Australian Mutual Provident Fire & General Insurance Co Ltd v Dixon [1982] VR 833 .
Legislation cited in [6.19.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 28.5.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 136.

Both under the present rule, and the complementary provision in UCPR r 28.5 (concerning consolidation of proceedings) the court has a general discretion to permit joinder even where the proceedings do not involve both “common” questions and relevant “sameness” of transactions.

The recognition of this discretion emerged from the long, and technically complex, history of similar rules relating to the joinder of causes of action and parties. That history reveals the general desirability of confining proceedings to the issues, particularly the relief issues, common to all of the disputing parties. It also reveals practical concern about the efficient determination of essentially similar issues, and the difficulty in formulating precise and acceptable criteria to distinguish between permissible and impermissible joinder. See the discussions in Smurthwaite v Hannay [1894] AC 494 at 500; (1894) 71 LT 157 per Lord Herschell LC & 503 per Lord Russell; and [1893] 2 QB 412 — especially at 420 per Lord Esher MR and 422–5 per Bowen LJ.

In deciding whether joinder leave should be granted, the basic principle is that the court should take the course most conducive to the just resolution of the dispute, having regard to the desirability of limiting the costs and delay of litigation: Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1991) ATPR ¶41-078; (1991) ASC ¶56-033; BC9001594. Relevant considerations include the costs and time saved by the joinder, as against any potential unfairness that may be occasioned to any party.

Where there are many applicants with interrelated claims involving many common questions of fact and law, it may be highly desirable to determine those questions in the same proceedings: Bishop v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1990) 25 FCR 311 . Similar desirability may exist where there are only a small number of claimants, but their claims are similar and rely on essentially the same misconduct allegations against the defendant parties: Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd, above (six family members and their family companies sued their financial adviser alleging the same terms of retainer and the same acts of negligence). Leave may be granted to join preference claims by related plaintiffs against multiple defendants, where the proceedings involve common questions concerning the solvency of the plaintiffs: Dean-Willcocks v Cmr of Taxation (2003) 45 ACSR 298; [2003] NSWSC 355; BC200302121 (common factual issue concerning solvency of related companies).

Joinder will generally be inappropriate where the transactions are essentially separate even though some of them involve common parties: Cheque One Pty Ltd v Cheque Exchange (Aust) Pty Ltd (in liq) (2002) ATPR ¶41-881; [2002] FCA 593; BC200202225 (twelve applicants relying on different representations by several of five different respondents). But this generality is subject to an essentially impressionistic assessment about the circumstances of the particular case. That assessment will often involve considering the practical benefits of a common determination of some issues, and the feasibility of appropriate directions to address adequately the interests of the parties in relation to costs of the proceedings and in relation to separate issues relating to them individually: Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Sydney Investment House Equities Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 434; BC200703269 (risk of prejudice from evidence inadmissible against individual parties could be resolved by determination under s 136 of the Evidence Act); Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Somerville [2008] NSWSC 788; BC200806954 (misconduct allegations against financial adviser — allegedly similar advice to multiple unrelated parties — joinder despite absence of “common” questions or “same” transactions).
Legislation cited in [6.19.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22(3), s 3, s 98.

The general meaning of “party” is that of a person who is formally named as a “party to the record” and does not include a person who merely has an interest in the outcome of the litigation: see R v Murray; Ex parte Commonwealth (1916) 22 CLR 437 at 469; 22 ALR 413; BC1600018 . But for the purpose of the limitation in awarding costs the word “party” is not confined to a person on the record in the proceedings: Knight v FP Special Assets Ltd (1992) 174 CLR 178 at 190; 66 ALJR 560; BC9202673 ; Victoria Legal Aid v County Court of Victoria (2004) 9 VR 686; [2004] VSCA 113; BC200404494 ; King v GIO Australia Holdings Ltd (2001) 116 FCR 509; [2001] FCA 1773; BC200107826 . It includes a person who actually participates in the determination of the issues in the proceedings: Law Society of New South Wales v Jackson [1981] 1 NSWLR 730 at 735 (Council of the Law Society participated in proceeding before the Statutory Committee); City of Burnside v A-G (SA) (1994) 63 SASR 65; BC9405368 (intervener opposing orders for the sale of land subject to a charitable trust); ACP Magazines Pty Ltd v Motion [2000] NSWSC 1169; BC200007600 at [34] (costs granted against entity that had “participated” in proceedings in respect of an unsuccessful claim for privilege for subpoenaed documents). There is no specific definition of “party” in the CPA and UCPR and no reason to confine it to persons who are formally on the record: Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 67 NSWLR 289; [2006] NSWSC 879; BC200606784 at [15] (costs order given against person subpoenaed to produce documents and unsuccessfully resisted the subpoena on grounds of legal professional privilege). Alternatively, given the terms of CPA s 22(3) and the definition of “claims for relief” in s 3 , then a claim for the determination of a question that could be determined by the court (even in separate proceedings) is a claim for relief under s 22. Persons against whom defendants make a claim for relief are thereby parties to proceedings and subject to a costs order under CPA s 98 : see ACP Magazines Pty Ltd v Motion [2000] NSWSC 1169; BC200007600 ; Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 67 NSWLR 289; [2006] NSWSC 879; BC200606784 . A tutor who commences and carries on proceedings on behalf of a person under legal incapacity is to be regarded as a party for the purposes of UCPR r 42.3(2)(c) (now repealed): see discussion in Yakmor v Hamdoush (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 284; BC200909126 at [24], [44], [45] (tutor to pay the costs of the appeal).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.20] r 6.20 Proceedings affecting persons having joint entitlement (cf SCR Part 8, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 7, rules 3 and 4; LCR Part 6, rules 3 and 4)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings affecting persons having joint entitlement (cf SCR Part 8, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 7, rules 3 and 4; LCR Part 6, rules 3 and 4)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, all persons jointly entitled to the same relief must be joined as parties in any claim for that relief that is made by any one or more of them.
Unless the court orders otherwise, any other such person is to be joined:
as a plaintiff, if he or she consents to being a plaintiff, or
as a defendant, if he or she does not consent to being a plaintiff.
Despite subrule (1), a person may not be joined as a party to proceedings in contravention of any other Act or law.
See, for example, section 62 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 of the Commonwealth.

level.toc-caption: [6.20.5] Mandatory joinder of persons jointly entitled

heading.title: Mandatory joinder of persons jointly entitled

p.text: It may be necessary, as a matter of practical reality, to offer an unwilling co-plaintiff an indemnity as to costs: Johnson v Stephens & Carter Ltd [1923] 2 KB 857 , as explained in Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 798 (if the unwilling party is joined as a defendant they may be entitled to apply for security): see also Australian Workers' Union v Bowen (1946) 72 CLR 575 at 586 ; Burnside v Harrison Marks Productions Ltd [1968] 2 All ER 286 ; Kapeleris v Bytenet Pty Ltd (1997) 15 ACLC 1,308 at 1,310-1,311. Alternatively, an unwilling plaintiff may be joined as a defendant, and should be so joined unless the court otherwise orders: Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 798 . Where persons are merely concurrently, rather than jointly, entitled their joinder is not mandatory but may be effected under rr 6.19 or 6.24 : see Manzo v 555/255 Pitt Street Pty Ltd (1990) 21 NSWLR 1 at 9A .

Section 62 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) provides that a bankrupt co-contractor need not be joined as a plaintiff. Where persons are concurrent holders of a right it is not necessary to make them parties: Scott v Tuff-Kote (Aust) Pty Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 537 (action to restrain misuse of the name “Lloyds of London”).
Legislation cited in [6.20.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

Notwithstanding the provisions of r 6.23 , if a plaintiff persists in the proceedings without joining all necessary parties, the court may dismiss the proceedings, see Kantichandra v Radhu Rahman (1930) AIR (CAL) 461; 127 IC 59 (India); Lochab Bros v Kenya Furfural [1985] Law Reports of the Commonwealth (Commercial) 737 at 750. Alternatively, the court may order that a person be joined as a party under r 6.24 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.21] r 6.21 Proceedings affecting persons having joint or several liability (cf SCR Part 8, rule 5; DCR Part 7, rule 5; LCR Part 6, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings affecting persons having joint or several liability (cf SCR Part 8, rule 5; DCR Part 7, rule 5; LCR Part 6, rule 5)

p.text: A person who is jointly and severally liable with some other person in relation to any act, matter or thing need not be a defendant in proceedings with respect to that act, matter or thing merely because the other person is a defendant in those proceedings.

In any proceedings in which a defendant is one of a number of persons who are jointly, but not severally, liable in contract or tort, or under an Act or statutory instrument, the court may order that the other persons be joined as defendants and that the proceedings be stayed until those other persons have been so joined.
Legislation cited in [6.21.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 95.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.21(2).

Ordinarily all joint debtors or tortfeasors should be joined in the proceedings. However, both CPA s 95 and the present rule permits proceedings to be brought, and judgment obtained, against individual joint debtors or tortfeasors. Similarly, the present rule permits a plaintiff to sue individual joint debtors or tortfeasors, subject to their right to apply under UCPR r 6.21(2) for a stay until the other prospective defendants have been joined. Rule 6.21(2) does not apply if the debtors or tortfeasors are both jointly and severally liable, or if they are only severally liable. There is a discretion as to whether an order should be made under r 6.21(2): Norbury Natzio & Co Ltd v Griffıths [1918] 2 KB 369 . An order will not be made if the plaintiff has already made every effort to find the missing defendant (Robinson v Geisel [1894] 2 QB 685 ) or if the missing defendant is overseas: Wilson, Sons & Co Ltd v Balcarres Brook Steamship Co Ltd [1893] 1 QB 422 . The order is made upon the defendant establishing a reasonable and probable case of joint liability, and without prejudice as to whether the liability is in fact joint: Fardell Traction Haulage Co Ltd v Basset (1899) 15 TLR 204 ; Norbury Natzio & Co Ltd v Griffıths , above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.22] r 6.22 Court may order separate trials if joinder of party or cause of action inconvenient (cf SCR Part 8, rule 6; DCR Part 7, rule 6; LCR Part 6, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Court may order separate trials if joinder of party or cause of action inconvenient (cf SCR Part 8, rule 6; DCR Part 7, rule 6; LCR Part 6, rule 6)

p.text: If the court considers that the joinder of parties or causes of action in any proceedings may embarrass, inconvenience or delay the conduct of the proceedings, the court:
may order separate trials, or
may make such other order as it thinks fit.

This rule gives the court power to deal with any inconvenience that might have been caused by the joinder. Any application under this rule should be made as soon as the inconvenience appears. The application may be made at the trial: Thomas v Moore [1918] 1 KB 555 at 569 . The ultimate onus is on the plaintiff to justify the joinder: Saccharin Corp Ltd v Wild [1903] 1 Ch 410 at 422 . But the convenience of all parties must be considered. This requires consideration of the prejudice that might be caused by evidence being called which is admissible on only one aspect of the case or only against individual parties: Sandes v Wildsmith [1893] 1 QB 771 at 774 . Delay in making the application can also be a relevant factor. Some examples where joinder was refused include South African Republic v La Compagne France-Belge Du Chemin De Fer Du Nord [1897] 2 Ch 487 (libel action and suit for declaration as to the appointment of trustees); Wood v Cross Television Centre Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 528; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 596 (disallowance of defamation cross-claim in debt proceedings); Rowan v Cornwall (SASC, Duggan J, No 1481/95, 4 September 1995, unreported, BC9503782) (order for separate trial of causes of action). The power under this rule will permit deconsolidation of proceedings (prior order for consolidation of two proceedings set aside): Strata Plan 61287 v Brookfield Multiplex Ltd [2011] NSWSC 1302 at [5]–[14] .

level.toc-caption: [6.22.10] Such order as the court thinks fit

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.22.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 31.

heading.title: Such order as the court thinks fit

p.text: The court has a wide discretion in dealing with an application under this rule. The court may make any order that it considers expedient. These may include the following orders:
an order striking out some causes of action: Wood v Cross Television Centre Pty Ltd [1962] NSWR 528; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 596 ;
an order requiring the plaintiff to elect the causes of action to be proceeded on: Universities of Oxford & Cambridge v Gill [1899] 1 Ch 55 ;
an order striking out parties;
an order requiring an election as to which of the plaintiffs should proceed: Sandes v Wildsmith [1893] 1 QB 771 ; Prisoners A to XX Inclusive v New South Wales (1995) 79 A Crim R 377; BC9505159 ;
an order excusing a defendant from attendance at part of the proceedings;

an order setting aside consolidation of proceedings, and permitting separate representation of the plaintiffs in the individual proceedings: Strata Plan 61287 v Brookfield Multiplex Ltd [2011] NSWSC 1302 at [5]–[14] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.23] r 6.23 Effect of misjoinder or non-joinder of parties (cf SCR Part 8, rule 7 (1); DCR Part 7, rule 7 (1); LCR Part 6, rule 7 (1))

leg:heading.title: Effect of misjoinder or non-joinder of parties (cf SCR Part 8, rule 7 (1); DCR Part 7, rule 7 (1); LCR Part 6, rule 7 (1))

p.text: Proceedings are not defeated merely because of the misjoinder or non-joinder of any person as a party to the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [6.23.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 19.2, rr 6.22, 6.24.

The rule does not detract from the proposition that all proper parties should normally be joined. Nevertheless, it does authorise the determination of issues in proceedings notwithstanding either the non-joinder, or misjoinder, of parties: Finance Corp of Australia Ltd v Bentley (1991) 5 BPR 11,833; BC9102015 per Mahoney JA, Handley JA agreeing. The statement in the rule that the proceedings “shall not be defeated” reinforces the powers of the court under rr 6.22 and 6.24 (and also the power of amendment in r 19.2 ) to ensure that the proceedings are properly constituted and that all appropriate parties are joined.

However a person who has not been joined as a party and is in fact affected by orders made in the proceedings, will be entitled to apply to have them set aside: Taylor v Taylor (1979) 143 CLR 1 at 4; 25 ALR 418 ; Finance Corp of Australia Ltd v Bentley (1991) 5 BPR 11,833; BC9102015 ; cf Chappuis v Filo (1990) 19 NSWLR 490 at 512 . There is also authority for the view that such a person has an entitlement to have the orders set aside, not just a right to apply for the favourable exercise of a discretion: John Alexander’s Clubs Pty Ltd v White City Tennis Club Ltd (2010) 241 CLR 1; 266 ALR 462; [2010] HCA 19; BC201003368 at [137].

Misjoinder should be distinguished from the misnomer or misdescription of a party's name. (Misnomer is rarely serious and an amendment will usually be granted to correct the error, but see J Robertson & Co Ltd (in liq) v Ferguson Transformers Pty Ltd [1971] ALR 377; (1970) 44 ALJR 441 , noted above.). The distinction may be critical where there is a statute of limitation which might preclude the substitution of an entirely new plaintiff or defendant, but which would be irrelevant if the mere correction of a party's name is sought: J Robertson & Co Ltd (in liq) v Ferguson Transformers Pty Ltd [1971] ALR 377; (1970) 44 ALJR 441 ; Attorney-General (UK) v Sorati [1969] VR 88 . See also Alexander Mountain & Co v Rumere Ltd [1948] 2 KB 436 ; Etablissement Baudelot v RS Graham & Co Ltd [1953] 2 QB 271 ; Davies v Elsby Bros Ltd [1960] 3 All ER 672; [1961] 1 WLR 170 ; Rainbow Spray Irrigation Pty Ltd v Hoette [1963] NSWR 1440; (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 142 . Examples of misnomer are:
the omission of “Limited” from a company’s title: Whittam v WJ Daniel & Co Ltd [1962] 1 QB 271 ;
naming a corporation sole by the personal name of the current holder of the office: Heinrick v A-G [1967] SASR 78 ;
using the words “& Son” or “& Co” after a persons name where that person is a sole trader: W Hill & Son v Tannerhill [1944] KB 472.

level.toc-caption: [6.23.15] Action commenced in name of deceased person

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.23.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 19.1(3).

heading.title: Action commenced in name of deceased person

p.text: When an action is commenced in the name of a deceased person, their representative cannot be substituted as a plaintiff: Tetlow v Orela Ltd [1920] 2 Ch 14; Clay v Oxford (1866) LR 2 Ex 54; Godfrey v President of Sydney Mechanics’ School of Arts (1894) 10 WN (NSW) 146; Re Transfer of Land Act; Ex parte Anderson [1911] VLR 397 ; Dawson (Bradford) Ltd v Dove [1971] 1 QB 330 ; Green v Philippines Consulate General [1971] VR 12 ; Maritime Services Board of New South Wales v Australian Chamber of Shipping [1977] 1 NSWLR 648 ; Marshall v DG Sundin & Co Pty Ltd (1989) 16 NSWLR 463 (originating process filed on the same day, but after, the plaintiff’s death); Budimir v McMahon [2000] FCA 1312; BC200005614 (bankruptcy notice issued in the name of a deceased creditor); Deveigne v Askar [2007] NSWCA 45; BC200701511 at [12] (proceedings commenced against a deceased defendant). Similarly where action has been commenced against a deceased person, the rule does not empower the court to substitute their executor as a party: Dawson (Bradford) Ltd v Dove [1971] 1 QB 330 . But the court can, under this rule and r 19.1(3) of the UCPR, substitute a post-merger company for a non-existent pre-merger company incorrectly named as a party: RKO Pictures Inc v Cannon Screen Entertainment Ltd [1990] BCLC 364 . But see RKO Pictures Inc v Cannon Screen Entertainment Ltd [1990] BCLC 364 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.24] r 6.24 Court may join party if joinder proper or necessary (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8 (1); DCR Part 7, rule 8 (1); LCR Part 6, rule 8 (1))

leg:heading.title: Court may join party if joinder proper or necessary (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8 (1); DCR Part 7, rule 8 (1); LCR Part 6, rule 8 (1))

p.text: If the court considers that a person ought to have been joined as a party, or is a person whose joinder as a party is necessary to the determination of all matters in dispute in any proceedings, the court may order that the person be joined as a party.

Without limiting subrule (1), in proceedings for the possession of land, the court may order that a person (not being a party to the proceedings) who is in possession of the whole or any part of the land (whether in person or by a tenant) be added as a defendant.

level.toc-caption: [6.24.5] Parties that ought to be joined

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.24.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.1.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 237.

heading.title: Parties that ought to be joined

p.text: The rule reflects the general proposition that all parties to disputes that relate to the same subject matter should generally be dealt with at the one time: Montgomery v Foy, Morgan & Co [1895] 2 QB 321 at 324 ; John Cooke & Co Pty Ltd v Commonwealth (1922) 31 CLR 394 at 411. So construed the rule reflects the court's general concern to achieve finality in litigation: see CPA s 90 and UCPR r 36.1 . The rule contains two elements, either of which may be relied upon to justify the addition of a party. Those elements are the joinder of a party who ought to have been made a party and the joinder of a “necessary” party.

The different wording of the two elements hints at a distinction between mandatory and discretionary joinder. The distinction may be illustrated by examples but, in truth, the definition of a precise distinction between, on the one hand, a party who “ought to have been joined and, on the other, a party whose joinder is “necessary”, is extremely difficult to formulate. As examples of situations where a party “ought to have been joined one can consider the following situations:

where a co-owner's rights in land may be affected by the litigation: Pralle v Scharka [1978] 2 NSWLR 450 (specific performance of contract for the sale of co-owner’s interest); Merrett v Babb [2001] QB 1174; [2001] 3 WLR 1 (claim for damages by co-purchasers);

where rights may be directly affected by a declaration to be made: London Passenger Transport Board v Moscrop [1942] AC 332 at 345 : such as proceedings to determine the meaning of a will: Rudge v Link [2008] NSWSC 1104; BC200809211 at [4]; or proceedings for a declaration concerning the validity of planning approval: Cambridge Credit Corp v Parkes Developments Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 590 at 615 (planning authority added as party);

or where rights may be indirectly affected by the proceedings: Peters v Coastace (2006) 57 ACSR 241; [2006] NSWSC 289; BC200602303 (application under s 237 of the Corporations Act for leave to bring proceedings on behalf of a corporation).

If a statute prescribes the permissible parties to proceedings the statute itself makes the present rule inapplicable: Tweed Shire Council v Minister administering the Crown Lands Act (1996) 92 LGERA 80; BC9604168 .
Legislation cited in [6.24.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 38.3, r 6.19.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 97.

The criterion of necessary joinder permits an ample discretion. But it does not authorise the reconstruction of proceedings by the substitution of a new plaintiff, with a new cause of action, for an old plaintiff whose cause of action is no longer maintainable: Knight v McCann-Erickson Advertising Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 26 August 1991, unreported, BC9101623). Nor can parties be joined after entry of judgment. Even before entry, joinder is inappropriate unless a substantive claim is to be made against the person concerned. (In so far as a joinder is sought by a plaintiff to make a substantive claim against the proposed new party the appropriate power is contained in UCPR r 6.19 : see Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Little Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 at 45–53 .) No joinder should be made merely to aid in the execution of the judgment: State Bank of New South Wales v MacDonald (NSWSC, Cole J, 17 January 1992, unreported, BC9202104). If it is necessary to obtain information from a person in order to proceed to enforce the judgment, the court may exercise its powers under CPA s 97 and UCPR r 38.3 : State Bank of New South Wales v MacDonald , above.

The phrase “all matters in dispute in the proceedings is not limited to matters that arise on the existing pleadings. It also includes ancillary or preliminary questions: Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Liddle Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 at 38 ; Birtles v Commonwealth [1960] VR 247 at 251 ; Black v Houghton [1968] Qd R 179 at 187 ; Chappell v Ballestrin [1965] SASR 47 at 49 . These may include such matters as the standing of the plaintiff to sue: Weddell v JA Pearce [1988] Ch 26; [1987] 3 All ER 624 (action commenced by equitable assignee — joinder of assignor).

level.toc-caption: [6.24.20] Necessary to ensure all matters completely adjudicated

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.24.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: Necessary to ensure all matters completely adjudicated

p.text: Consistent with the overriding purpose set out in CPA s 56 , the criterion of necessary joinder requires consideration of the proper determination of all the matters in dispute in the proceedings. While it is not sufficient merely to show that the joinder is just or convenient: Vandervell Trustees Ltd v White [1971] AC 912; [1970] 3 All ER 16 (no joinder of the revenue authorities in private litigation involving tax issues); it is difficult, and perhaps undesirable, to attempt an exhaustive formulation of a principle as to when joinder is “necessary”: Gurtner v Circuit [1968] 2 QB 587; [1968] 1 All ER 328 ; Re Great Eastern Cleaning Services Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 278 . The rule has been linked in the decided cases to the necessity of ensuring that the rules of natural justice are observed: Pegang Mining Co Ltd v Choon Sam [1969] 2 MLJ 52 ; Dwyer v Burns Philp Trustee Co Ltd (NSWSC, Waddell CJ in Eq, 17 February 1989, unreported). In Gurtner v Circuit , above, Diplock LJ, addressing the natural justice considerations relevant to the question of joinder, said that a matter was not “effectually and completely determined and adjudicated upon unless all those who would be liable to satisfy the judgment were given an opportunity to be heard. He also said that the rules of natural justice did not “depend upon a technicality as to the procedure by which the liability of a person who is bound to satisfy the judgment … is enforceable. So long as it is legally enforceable against that person either directly by the plaintiff or indirectly … for the plaintiff's benefit … the court has jurisdiction to add that person as a party and ought normally to exercise its discretion by granting his application to be added”. The court may order the addition of an owners' corporation as a plaintiff where, under an exception to the “proper plaintiff rule (in Foss v Harbottle (1843) 2 Hare 461; 67 ER 189 ), it is just to do so: Carre v Owners Corp — Strata Plan 53020 (2003) 58 NSWLR 302; [2003] NSWSC 397; BC200302275 .

level.toc-caption: [6.24.25] Necessity for joinder — indirect practical effect

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.24.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Family Provision Act 1982.

heading.title: Necessity for joinder — indirect practical effect

p.text: Examples of the application of the principles contained in the decided cases have fluctuated between “wider” (for example, Gurtner v Circuit [1968] 2 QB 587; [1968] 1 All ER 328 ; McIntosh v Williams [1979] 2 NSWLR 543 (compensation to relatives claim — joinder of tutor of ex-nuptial child of disputed paternity) — direct legal effect required) and “narrower” (eg, Amon v Raphael Tuck & Sons Ltd [1956] 1 QB 357 — indirect practical effect sufficient) interpretations of the requirement of necessity. The question whether the rule extends to permit joinder of a party who has a “commercial rather than a legal interest is discussed in Amon v Raphael Tuck & Sons Ltd , above; Gurtner v Circuit , above; Vandervell Trustees Ltd v White [1971] AC 912 at 930, 935–6; [1970] 3 All ER 16 ; Bradvica v Radulovic [1975] VR 434 ; Coolibah Pty Ltd v Cmr of Taxation [1981] Qd R 69 at 71 . (In the latter two cases the relevant rule referred to “all questions involved in the cause or matter” and may have had an arguably wider scope than the present rule.) See also SCI Operations Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1984) 2 FCR 113; 53 ALR 283 at 328 ; Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 148 CLR 150; 37 ALR 66; BC8100114 ; Hughes Motor Service Pty Ltd v Wang Computer Pty Ltd (1978) 35 FLR 346 at 351 (joinder of parties to an appeal); John Cooke & Co Pty Ltd v Commonwealth (1922) 31 CLR 394 (competing claimants to a fund). In Pegang Mining Co Ltd v Choon Sam [1969] 2 MLJ 52 at 56 , Lord Diplock said “While their Lordships agree that the mere fact that a person is likely to be better off financially if a case is decided one way rather than another is not a sufficient ground to entitle him to be added as a party, they do not find the dichotomy between ‘legal’ and ‘commercial’ interests helpful”. A better way of expressing the test is: Will his rights against or liabilities to any party to the action in respect of the subject matter of the action be directly affected by any order which may be made in the action? If the answer to this question is “yes”, then that person should be added as a party. The test has been applied in South Australia in Re Multi-Tech Services Pty Ltd (in liq) (1982) 30 SASR 218 at 221 ; and also in News Ltd v Australian Rugby Football League Ltd (1996) 64 FCR 410; 139 ALR 193; BC9604667 (effect of orders on third party). But perhaps even this test does not sufficiently indicate the breadth of the discretion available under the present rule.
Examples of the application of the rule cannot be given exhaustively, but some illustrations are informative:

Armidale Dumaresq Council v Attorney-General (NSW) (No 1) [2007] NSWSC 557; BC200706850 — charitable trust proceedings where the Attorney General was not taking an active part and an interested incorporated association was joined as a party to contest the proceedings.

Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd v Parkes Developments Pty Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 590 — the validity of a development approval was challenged on the ground of a council's non-compliance with legislative requirements, it was said that the council should have been joined; even though the only effect of the judgment would (arguably) have been to inform the council of the invalidity of the procedures under which it had operated.

Dwyer v Burns Philp Trustee Co Ltd (SC(NSW), Waddell CJ in Eq, 17 February 1989, unreported) (application refused on the facts) — the rule can be used to join beneficiaries of an estate as defendants to proceedings under the Family Provision Act 1982 if the defendant executor does not properly present the case.

Foxe v Brown (1984) 58 ALR 542; 59 ALJR 186; BC8400466 — the equivalent High Court rule was held to permit the joinder of a third party insurer in circumstances where the individual defendant could not be served: compare Savaglia v MacLennan (1980) 24 SASR 314 .

Hammond v JP Morgan Trust Australia Ltd [2012] NSWCA 261; BC201206281 at [12]–[19] (application refused) — husband claimed his wife held land on resulting trust for him, his asserted equitable interest had no priority over a first registered mortgage, and the husband was not a necessary party to the mortgagee’s possession proceedings against the wife) upheld in Hammond v JP Morgan Trust Australia Ltd (2012) 16 BPR 30,901; [2012] NSWCA 295; BC201207363 at [69]ff.

Keating v Dickson (1991) 23 NSWLR 433 — a candidate in a parliamentary election challenged the validity of legislation which regulated the formality of votes cast, another candidate was added under this to this rule.

level.toc-caption: [6.24.30] Defendant — no joinder where no relief claimed against

heading.title: Defendant — no joinder where no relief claimed against

p.text: The fact that the party sought to be joined is one against whom no relief is sought, either by way of declaration or otherwise, will ordinarily indicate that the joinder is not necessary: Vandervell Trustees Ltd v White [1971] AC 912 at 944; [1970] 3 All ER 16 ; Walker v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia (1985) 3 NSWLR 496 (impermissible joinder of sureties where payment challenged as a recoverable preference). A proposed joinder does not satisfy the test of necessity if its only purpose is to have the proposed party bound by the decision and no relief is claimed directly against it: Re A Singer and Co (Hat Manufacturers) Ltd [1943] Ch 121 ; Walker v Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, above; not following Re Multi-Tech Services Pty Ltd (in liq) (1982) 30 SASR 218 at 221 . The position may be different, however, where the person seeking to be joined will be affected indirectly by the court's order and where the existing parties have no interest in raising matters relevant to the applicant's position: Re Great Eastern Cleaning Services Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 278 . In that case the Commissioner of Taxation applied to be joined in proceedings brought by X to restore a company to the register. If the restoration proceedings had been successful the restoration would have destroyed the commissioner's rights against X in other proceedings: compare Re Rown Pty Ltd (1981) 5 ACLR 745 and Vandervell Trustees Ltd v White [1971] AC 912; [1970] 3 All ER 16 (no joinder of the revenue authorities in private litigation involving tax issues).
Legislation cited in [6.24.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Insurance Act 1902 s 17A.

A plaintiff is generally entitled to choose whether to proceed against particular defendants. Accordingly, if the proposed defendant is not a person who “ought to have been joined under any of the rules, a contested application to require a plaintiff to add a defendant will not normally be granted. This is especially so if the plaintiff claims no relief against the proposed defendant: Atid Navigation Co Ltd v Fairplay Towage & Shipping Co Ltd [1955] 1 All ER 698; [1955] 1 WLR 336 ; Norris v Beazley (1877) 2 CPD 80 at 85 ; Dollfus Mieg et Compagnie SA v Bank of England [1951] Ch 33 ; Foxe v Brown (1984) 58 ALR 542 at 544; 59 ALJR 186; BC8400466 ; Rap Industries Pty Ltd v Royal Insurance Australia Ltd (1988) 5 ANZ Ins Cas ¶60-876; Santos v American Home Assurance Co (1986) 4 ANZ Ins Cas ¶60-795 (defendant insurer's unsuccessful application to join a cross-defendant to assert a contingent right of subrogation). However, there is no absolute proposition to that effect and the general position may be departed from in appropriate cases. Thus a defendant insurer may be able to require a plaintiff to join a third party as a defendant where the insurer, if liable under the policy, would be subrogated to the plaintiff's rights against the third party (Patricks Operations Pty Ltd v American Home Assurance Co (NSWSC, Rogers CJ in Comm D, 23 February 1989, unreported, BC8902506)), however the insurer would have to provide the plaintiff with an indemnity for costs. As to an insurer's statutory entitlement to join in proceedings between the insured and a third party when the insurer alleges the insurance claim has not been made in good faith, see Insurance Act 1902 s 17A .
Legislation cited in [6.24.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.19, r 6.28, r 6.32.

Where it is the plaintiff who applies to add a defendant, the scope of the “matters in dispute in the action” should not be construed as limited to matters arising on the existing pleadings — on the basis that plaintiffs generally have a right to sue whom they choose, and that joinder could therefore have been made without leave when the plaintiff filed the originating process: Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Little Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 . It may also properly include those disputed issues of fact which are “subjacent to the pleadings”, and when the plaintiff asserts on tenable grounds that such matters of dispute cannot be properly determined without the joinder of another person as a party, a ground for the exercise of the power given by the rule is made out: Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Little Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 at 38 per Glass JA. In practice r 6.24 is closely related to r 6.19 (joinder of parties generally) and r 6.32 (removal of parties). Thus, where an action has, through a bona fide mistake, been commenced in the name of the wrong person as plaintiff, the fact that the original plaintiff has no cause of action does not take away the jurisdiction of the court to order the substitution of another person as plaintiff: Hughes v Pump House Hotel Co Ltd (No 2) [1902] 2 KB 485 . Leave to add a defendant will not be granted under the rule after the expiry of a relevant limitation period as regards action against the person proposed to be joined as defendant: Stout v RA Wenham Builders Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 426 . See also r 6.28 , which provides that “if the court orders that a person be joined as a party, the date of commencement of the proceedings, in relation to that person, is taken to be the date on which the order is made or such later date as the court may specify in the order”.
The situation will be viewed differently where it is the plaintiff who seeks to add a defendant to existing proceedings (Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Little Pty Ltd).

level.toc-caption: [6.24.45] Joinder not to defeat accrued limitation defence

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.24.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Limitation Act 1969.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 588FF.

heading.title: Joinder not to defeat accrued limitation defence

p.text: A formal amendment of the proceedings will be necessary to join a party to the proceedings. Because the date of commencement of proceedings against an added party is the date the amendment is made, the joinder cannot deprive a party of an accrued defence under the Limitation Act 1969 . Therefore if the party sought to be joined already has such a defence, there is a proper basis for refusing to permit the joinder: Ketteman v Hansel Properties Ltd [1987] 1 AC 189; [1988] 1 All ER 38 ; Stout v RA Wenham Builders Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 426; Drinan v Hickey (1982) 11 NSWLR 744 ; Kovacevic v Tycan Australia Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 25 June 1991, unreported, BC9101854); Seabridge v H Cox & Sons (Plant Hire) Ltd [1968] 2 QB 46; Braniff v Holland & Hannen & Cubitts (Southern) Ltd [1969] 1 WLR 1533; compare Archie v Archie [1980] Qd R 546 at 561 ; Adam v Shiavon [1985] 1 Qd R 1 at 7 and Marubeni Corp v Pearlstone Shipping Corp (The Puerto Acevedo) [1978] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 38. But joinder is permissible where it is, in effect, no more than the substitution of a party which has succeeded to the rights or obligations of an existing party against whom the proceedings were commenced within the limitation period: Yorkshire Regional Authority v Fairclough Building Ltd [1996] 1 WLR 210 (statutory transfer of cause of action); Industrie Chimiche Italia Centrale v Alexander Tsavirilis & Sons Maritime Co (The Choko Star) [1996] 1 All ER 114; [1996] 1 WLR 774 (merger pursuant to which foreign law subjected the merged corporation to the rights and obligations of the former party). Joinder is also permissible if, as a matter of construction, the limitation period does not apply in the circumstances of the proposed joinder: BP Australia Ltd v Brown (2003) 58 NSWLR 322; 46 ACSR 677; [2003] NSWCA 216; BC200304438 (joinder of additional parties where a liquidator commenced avoidance proceedings under s 588FF of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) within the permitted statutory period).

level.toc-caption: [6.24.50] Intervention by non parties — power to permit

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.24.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1330(1).
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 ss 156–159, 559.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 23.

heading.title: Intervention by non parties — power to permit

p.text: Rule 6.24 will permit intervention where the intervener demonstrates the necessity of their joinder in the proceedings as a party. In addition, specific rights of intervention exist under other legislation: for example, Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 1330(1) (right of intervention conferred on the Australian Securities Commission); Legal Profession Act 2004 ss 156–159 , 559 (right of the relevant professional Council to intervene or appear). The question arises, however, as to whether the court can permit intervention in cases outside either the present rule or these specific statutory provisions. In New South Wales, the decision of the Court of Appeal in Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391 is authority for the proposition that there is no inherent power to order that an intervener be joined as a party: see also EI Du Pont de Nemours & Co v Cmr of Patents (No 5) (1989) 17 NSWLR 389 at 391 . Bradley has since been questioned, principally on the basis that the court there did not refer to Supreme Court Act 1970 s 23 : see Rushby v Roberts [1983] 1 NSWLR 350 at 353–5 per Street CJ, contra Hutley JA at 360, 363; Shales v Lieschke (1985) 3 NSWLR 65 at 80–1; 10 Fam LR 261 per Kirby P, at 89–90 per Priestley JA. Bradley was distinguished in Parke Davis Pty Ltd v Sanofi (1981) 54 FLR 122 on the grounds that patent extension proceedings are not solely inter partes, so that persons entitled to caveat under Patents Act 1990 (Cth) s 91 could be joined as parties.
In Australian Railways Union v Victorian Railways Cmrs (1930) 44 CLR 319 at 331; 37 ALR 37 , Dixon J said:

Normally parties, and parties alone appear in litigation. But, by a very special practice, the intervention of the States and the Commonwealth as persons interested has been permitted by the discretion of the court in matters which arise under the Constitution. The discretion to permit appearances by counsel is a very wide one; but I would think we would be wise to exercise it by allowing only those to be heard who wish to maintain some particular right, power or immunity in which they are concerned, and not merely to intervene to contend for what they consider to be a desirable state of the general law.

This statement of principle is clearly applicable to the exercise of the discretion conferred by the present rule. It is clear that leave to intervene would not be granted “to a mere busybody who was interfering in things which did not concern him”: R v Paddington Valuation Officer [1966] 1 QB 380 at 401 . In England, similar rules have been held to allow intervention in five classes of cases, though it has been recognised that the classes are not closed:
in a representative action where the plaintiff claims to represent the class of people including the intervenor, who is not willing to be so represented;
where the intervenor's proprietary rights or the enjoyment of his or her legal rights are affected;
in a specific performance suit where the intervenor is affected by the question of the manner in which the contract should be performed;

where the order which the plaintiff seeks directly affects the enjoyment of the intervenor's legal rights as opposed to his or her commercial interests: see Dollfus Mieg et Compagnie SA v Bank of England [1951] Ch 33 at 39–40 ;

in private proceedings that may affect the prerogatives of the Crown: Adams v Adams [1971] P 188 . This decision has not been followed in New South Wales, where it has been held that any such right would be subversive of the independence of the judiciary: Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391 at 402–4 . The more conservative view, against permitting interference by strangers in litigation between other parties, expressed in Amon v Raphael Tuck & Sons Ltd [1956] 1 QB 357 , seems thus to have been discarded in England (Gurtner v Circuit [1968] 2 QB 587; [1968] 1 All ER 328 ; Pegang Mining Co Ltd v Choon Sam [1969] 2 MLJ 52 ); in Victoria (Bradvica v Radulovic [1975] VR 434 ); and in South Australia: Re Multi-Tech Services Pty Ltd (in liq) (1982) 30 SASR 218 .

Instead of allowing intervention and formally joining a person as a party to the proceedings, a court may allow the person to be heard as an amicus curiae. The functions of an amicus curiae, and the circumstances in which persons may be heard in that role, have been the subject of discussion in the cases without being clearly defined: Johnson v Sammon (1974) 7 SASR 431 at 433 . The matter is entirely in the discretion of the court: Levy v Victoria (1997) 189 CLR 579; 146 ALR 248; [1997] HCA 31; BC9703254 per Brennan J, and an amicus curiae may be heard whenever the court thinks it proper: United States Tobacco Co v Minister for Consumer Affairs (1988) 19 FCR 184 at 199–201; 15 ALD 591 (Einfeld J); United States Tobacco Co v Minister for Consumer Affairs (1988) 20 FCR 520 at 533–8; 83 ALR 79 (Full Court) (where the history and development of the role of amicus curiae is discussed). Questions relevant to the decision whether to allow appearances as amicus curiae include (i) whether the appearance is apt to assist the court in the resolution of the proceedings (for example, by dealing with a point the parties have declined to argue: R v Tomkins [1985] 2 NZLR 253 at 254 ), (ii) whether the appearance is in the interest of the parties, (iii) whether the appearance will occupy time unnecessarily and (iv) whether the appearance will add inappropriately to the cost of the proceedings. The extent to which the amicus takes part in the conduct of the proceedings is a matter for the discretion of the court. At one time there were restrictions on the extent to which an amicus was allowed to participate in the conduct of the hearing in relation to the adducing of evidence and the examination of witnesses: see Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391 at 398–9 . But increasingly the courts have taken the view that the extent of the amicus' participation is a matter that depends on the circumstances of the particular case: Commonwealth v Tasmania (1983) 158 CLR 1; 46 ALR 625; BC8300075 ; National Australia Bank Ltd v Hokit Pty Ltd (1996) 39 NSWLR 377; BC9602450 ; Breen v Williams (1994) 35 NSWLR 522 at 532; BC9403477 . Necessarily the amicus will be permitted to address submissions to the court: Morelle Ltd v Wakeling [1955] 2 QB 379 ; but it may be appropriate to limit the appearance to matters of public importance that have not adequately been dealt with by the parties.

A person who is granted leave to intervene becomes a party to the proceedings. They have all the privileges of a party and can tender evidence, participate fully in all aspects of the argument and appeal: Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391 at 396 . If, however, a statute gives a person a right to appear and be heard “as if he were a party”, that person is not a party and accordingly may not appeal: Sydney Legacy Appeals Fund v Tanna (1980) 48 LGRA 98 . A person who has been joined improperly may not be able to appeal: Re Laymar Constructions Pty Ltd (1977) 3 ACLR 65 (no adverse determination made, but no formal order dismissing the party from the proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [6.24.70] Intervention — special rule in probate cases

heading.title: Intervention — special rule in probate cases

p.text: In a probate suit, any person who has an interest may be made a party by intervening. Indeed if such a person has knowledge of the proceedings, does not intervene and is “content to stand by and let his battle be fought by somebody else in the same interest”, he will be bound by the result and will not be able to reopen the matter subsequently: Osborne v Smith (1960) 105 CLR 153 at 158–9; [1961] ALR 831 and cases there cited.

level.toc-caption: [6.24.75] Plaintiff — joinder opposed by existing plaintiff

heading.title: Plaintiff — joinder opposed by existing plaintiff

p.text: As a rule, a co-plaintiff will not be joined on the defendant's application without the plaintiff's consent. In appropriate circumstances the proceedings may be stayed if the plaintiff does not consent: see Roberts v Holland [1893] 1 QB 665 .

Read in conjunction with r 6.29 & r 6.32(1)(d), the rule gives power to substitute plaintiffs or defendants. The jurisdiction to add or substitute is not confined to cases where there has been a mistake in the names of the original parties (Hughes v Pump House Hotel Co Ltd (No 2) [1902] 2 KB 485 ) and extends to representative proceedings: see Moon v Atherton [1972] 2 QB 435; [1972] 3 All ER 145 (where proceedings commenced by 10 persons as representative plaintiffs were permitted to continue in the name of one of the original 10). See also the judgment in Zurek v Budge (NSWSC, Gressier M, 25 March 1987, unreported).

A plaintiff may usually add a defendant at any stage by leave on paying the costs of and thrown away by the amendment. Amendments as to parties may even be made in the Court of Appeal if that seems just: Farley and Lewers Ltd v A-G [1963] SR (NSW) 814 ; Mulcahy v Curramore Pty Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 464 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.25] r 6.25 Joinder as plaintiff requires party’s consent (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8 (2); DCR Part 7, rule 8 (2); LCR Part 6, rule 8 (2))

leg:heading.title: Joinder as plaintiff requires party’s consent (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8 (2); DCR Part 7, rule 8 (2); LCR Part 6, rule 8 (2))

p.text: A person is not to be joined as a plaintiff in any proceedings except with his or her consent.

No order should be made adding a person as a plaintiff until their formal consents have been filed. The consent ought be in writing and signed by the person, rather than their solicitor: Fricker v Van Grutten [1896] 2 Ch 649 ; Re Lane; Glasson v Union Trustee Co of Australia Ltd [1931] QWN 48 ; even though r 7.24 arguably gives the person’s solicitor authority to sign the consent. The rule applies even where the new plaintiff is a trustee for an existing plaintiff: Besley v Besley (1888) 37 Ch D 648 ; Tryon v National Provident Institution (1886) 16 QBD 678 ; Greater Perth Real Estate Co Ltd v Johnson (1930) 32 WALR 99 . Where a person has been made a plaintiff in an action without proper authority, and adverse orders have without their knowledge the practice is to stay the proceedings, and to strike out the person's name for the purpose of future proceedings: Fricker v Van Grutten, above, following Reynolds v Howell (1873) LR 8 QB 398; Nurse v Dunford (1879) 13 Ch D 764 and Newbiggin-By-The-Sea Gas Co v Armstrong (1879) 13 Ch D 310 . A solicitor who purports to act on behalf of an intended plaintiff, but acts without their authority, will be ordered to pay the costs of the unauthorised proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.26] r 6.26 Joinder to recover costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 4 (3) and (4))

leg:heading.title: Joinder to recover costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 4 (3) and (4))

p.text: A person is not to be joined as a plaintiff in any proceedings except with his or her consent.

Except to the extent to which these rules expressly provide, a party may not join another person as a party to any proceedings for the purpose of making an application for costs against the other person.
This rule does not apply:
if the other person would otherwise be a proper party to the proceedings, or
if the party joins the other person by means of a cross-claim in respect of a claim for costs against the party.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.27] r 6.27 Joinder on application of third party (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8; DCR Part 7, rule 8; LCR Part 6, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Joinder on application of third party (cf SCR Part 8, rule 8; DCR Part 7, rule 8; LCR Part 6, rule 8)

p.text: A person who is not a party may apply to the court to be joined as a party, either as a plaintiff or defendant.
See the notes to r 6.22.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.28] r 6.28 Date of commencement of proceedings in relation to parties joined (cf SCR Part 8, rule 11 (3) and (4); DCR Part 7, rule 11 (3); LCR Part 6, rule 11 (3))

leg:heading.title: Date of commencement of proceedings in relation to parties joined (cf SCR Part 8, rule 11 (3) and (4); DCR Part 7, rule 11 (3); LCR Part 6, rule 11 (3))

p.text: If the court orders that a person be joined as a party, the date of commencement of the proceedings, in relation to that person, is taken to be the date on which the order is made or such later date as the court may specify in the order.

level.toc-caption: [6.28.5] Date of commencement of proceedings against added party

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.28.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.32, r 7.4.

heading.title: Date of commencement of proceedings against added party

p.text: Where a person is added as a party to the proceedings pursuant to the present rule, the date of the commencement of the proceedings against that party is the date of the order, unless the court specifies a later date. If a party is joined by amendment (other than an amendment directed under r 6.32 ), or pursuant to leave under rr 6.19, the person becomes a party on the filing of the relevant originating process naming them as a party. The rule relating to an order joining a party settles the position considered in decisions concerning similar joinder powers in previous provisions of the Supreme Court rules: see Fernance v Nominal Defendant (1989) 17 NSWLR 710 ; Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Liddle Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 at 45 ; and contrast Australian Coastal Shipping Commission v Curtis Cruising Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 734 . Persons represented in proceedings commenced pursuant to r 7.4 , are not parties. Consequently, if continuation of the proceedings is disallowed under that rule, a represented person cannot be joined thereafter if an applicable limitation period expired after the commencement of the proceedings: Ekaton Corp Pty Ltd v Shahin Enterprises Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 1018; BC200306653 .
